messageBody:
FYI, a few more reactions and articles on the same topic. It looks like
most of the Java and Ruby communities (last link) are typically using a
small portion of TDD and a majority of regular testing, which matches my
experience.

The good news is that they're all testing.

On 8/3/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
>
>
>
> On 8/3/06, Robert Martin < UncleBob@...> wrote:
>
> > > Hehe... If I'm a heretic because I recommend using your common sense
> > > instead of one-liners such as "always test first", then yes, guilty as
> > > charged :-)
> >
> > I have grown intolerant of the attitude that testing is optional.
>
>
> I never said testing was optional.
>
> I don't know about you, but what makes my job fascinating is that it's a
> constant mix of tasks with sometimes conflicting objectives:
>
> - Designing
> - Working with product managers
> - Coding
> - Debugging
> - Testing
> - Working with tech writers
> - Shipping
> - Supporting
>
> I am paid to make decisions in all these areas and prioritize them, and in
> order to ship good software, you need to score very well on all of these
> counts.
>
> The respective priorities of these tasks change depending on which cycle
> in your software development you are, and while testing is a high priority
> task in my mind at all times, it's obvious that at some point, it needs to
> be preempted by more urgent tasks.
>
> What makes someone a good professional is knowing when such a situation
> arises.
>
> What makes someone a bad professional is when they put a task at the top
> of their priority regardless of the context.
>
> --
> Cédric
> http://testng.org<http://www.google.com/url?sa=D&q=http%3A%2F%2Ftestng.org>
>
>


--
Cédric
